posts.cooked: Hey, 3324 here, I am here to try and provide some simple elevator code for Java. Probably isn’t the best, but I figured more results and resources couldn’t be bad. Also looking for any improvements or potential issues, as I haven’t run it on a real elevator yet.

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked:
I might be wrong here but for feedforward you’ll want to use the measured position and velocity instead of the trapezoid motion profile state

Also to handle the limit switch you could set the position / setpoint / current state to whatever the digital input is supposed to be at instead of 0. since otherwise, if the digital input is trigger at, say, 0.1 meters then you could trigger a loop (it tries to go down and it’s current position is always set higher than the setpoint, or if the encoder is set to 0 then you have added an offset to the system), it would be better to set the current state, setpoint, and measured position to a constant instead of 0. And to handle safe zones you could have a piece of code which clamps the setpoint periodically before you do any steps, that way it isn’t ever possible for the setpoint to be larger or smaller than the limits (it can be put in a conditional if you need the behavior for homing)

Also using the motor controller’s pid loop is going to give you better results than the wpilib pid! Other than that this looks amazing! Thank you so much for sharing this resource!

Thank you for the feedback, the code has been edited to reflect those suggestions! We simply went for the WPILib PID loops because it is something we know how to use, and we figured the results probably wouldn’t be measurably worse after tuning.

posts.cooked: I think I implemented it in a way where it should work though? I may be mistaken

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Well, that’s the fun part about control systems. “Works” is in the eye of the beholder. As long as it scores all the points you care to score, we have little to discuss .

That being said… No, I would not teach my students that “feedforward” logic involves sensing the state of the plant.

Generally, the way I explain “feedforward” to my students goes like this:

Pretend you are blindfolded, but really good at moving a joystick in repeatable ways.

I tell you exactly how much you need to deflect the joystick to get a certain acceleration and speed out of the robot.

I then tell you I need to accelerate by a certain amount, keep going for a certain time, then slow back down. Generally, what do you do to the joystick?

The student generally will respond “push it hard to get started, hold it steady to keep going for just the right amount of time, then back off (maybe to zero) to slow down to a stop”.

I say, “Great, that’s basically what you need to do for feed-forward”. And then we dive into the math and code to figure out exactly how much to “deflect the joystick” at a given time.

Through that work, we discover, no, a sensor is not needed.
So from my understanding, my original implementation of the trapezoidal movement system was “better” in this regard?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
If you’re looking for the simple answer: Yes. What you posted initially is “better”.

But I’m also pushing you to uncover deeper truths.

First and foremost, “better” can have many definitions. I’m not saying that my answer is guaranteed to score you more points, for example.

Secondly, knowledge sharing is important. WPILib writes docs for this purpose, and the docs are open-source for a reason. If you have learned something on your team which would contradict best-practices in the docs, it’s worthy at least to be discussed, and possibly to be PR’ed as a change so future seasons of students might learn from it too.
